Like all vacations, mine had to end too. After three wonderful
weeks of driving some 4200 miles from Minneapolis to Oregon and
back (taking in the Badlands, Black Hills, Big Homs, Yellowstone,
Grand Tetons, a ranch, and Glacier Park), I’m back at the office
again.
Things are busy here, as they must be for you too. During
the week of September 9 through 13 I attended an excellent seminar
in Washington on Instructional Television tinder DAVI auspices
(with Fund for the Advancement of Education funds). This week is
the hectic—but good—first week of broadcasting over KTCA«TV.
With the University of Minnesota contributing an hour a day from
its own studios, we’ve been plenty busy (along with a lot of other
NAEB members and non~members who also have been doing Channel 2
programs.)
As you know, the NAEB convention will meet in St. Louis on
October 30 and 31, and November 1. Board meetings are scheduled
for Monday, October 28, from 4*0° to 6s00 and 8s00 to exhaustion,
as well as Tuesday, October 29, from 9*00 to 12s00 and Is30 to
5s00. (The opening convention session will be held Tuesday night,
October 29•)
I hope you all can be there for all Board meetings. If you
can’t make it, would you drop me a line to that effect right away?
Whether or not you can come, would you send in suggestions
for the agenda? Harry and the headquarters staff are getting up
an agenda book to facilitate our consideration of those matters
requiring documentation, and in addition will send us advance copies
of some materiel so that we may read it before the meeting convenes.
There, of course, will be the usual reports, headquarters and
otherwise; but I hope we can devote the major portion of our time
to long range planning and policy problems.
On my temporary agenda list are the followings (1) lesi®lative
problems (such as Magnuson and Eberharter bills, tax relief for
UHF) (Lennie Marks will be on hand to guide us here); (2) other
legal problems (including insurance); (3) FCC probisms (current
developments on which we should be informed, and on which we may
have to take positions); (4) ETRC and JCET relationships and
policies; seminar plans; regional meetings; constitutional problems;
permanent financing problems.
What else? May I hear from you?
BPskis
